Second step: 4 NaBr + H2SO4 + 2 HClO ---------- Na2SO4 + 2 NaCl + 2 H2O + 2 Br2.

As teenager I made very small amounts of bromine from potassium bromide. It is extremely irritating and a small amount of can cause a burning sensations in the throat. Nothing will relieve that burning. One just has to let it wear off. Bromine should never be allowed to come into contact with acetone. This generates bromoactone, also known as tear gas.

As an adult I worked wilth kilogram quantities of bromine for a small chemical company. We worked on pilot plant scale much of the time. Kilogram quanties of bromine were much more difficult to handle than a gram or so. The vapors from the kilogram quanties would burn the skin.

About gasoline in the past: It was cheaper to add tetraethyl lead, Pb(CH2CH3)4, to gasline for anti-knock than to catylically treat it so it wouldnt knock. When the gas burned lead was left so brominated hydrocarbons were and which made bromine which combined with the lead. It was a dirty burn that caused a lot of pollution. The engine released lead bromide and hydrogen bromide into the environment. The lead bromide and hydrobromic acid, corroded the engine and especially the exhaust pipes. Every few years they had to be replaced.

In the late '70s it was possible to purchase potassium bromide from the chemist and nitric acid from the chemical retailer.
I would combine this and distill the bromine in a glass retort.
The byproduct remaining in the retort was a potassium nitrate solution. Tip it out into a beaker before the saturated solution cooled or it will crystallize in the retort.

As far as I know, the process using chlorine gas is pretty dangerous and not too efficient, especially on small-scale experiments, because some of the excess chlorine can react with bromine to form BrCl. This may also be the reason why a smaller amount of chlorine than stochiometric works better. Also, a little bit of Bromine in a solution of excess chloride may form BrCl2- ions. I found on the internet that dead sea salt contains quite a bit of bromide, so I started an electrolysis in separate chambers, and, as expected, first the color went slowly to a kind of red-ish orange, but after some time it converted to a pale yellow. I think that the first bit of chlorine produced by the electrolysis was oxidizing the bromide to tribromide (The electrolysis itself might have done that too, at least for a little bit, but as the solution contained mostly chloride this was probably the main anion that was oxidized), but as time progressed, it was further oxidized to bromine, which partly reacted with the chloride to form BrCl2- and partly reacted with chlorine to form first BrCl, which again reacted with chloride to form BrCl2-.
That was an interesting result, I'd appreciate if some of you who know that stuff better than me could check if I was correct!

Years ago I found a much easier way to make bromine. No distillation required. Simply dissolve the sodium bromide in as little water as will fully dissolve it, add a stoichiometric quantity of hydrochloric acid, and then add bleach to that mixture. The bromine will settle on the bottom of the mixing flask, and can then be extracted with a dropper. Super easy. I can make as much bromine as I want in about two minutes.

Some bromine will stay dissolved in the solution, but you'll get most of it out, and since the ingredients are cheap it's not worth going through the distillation process to get it all out.

Iodine can be made the exact same way, but with iodide instead of bromide.

This is essentially a redox reaction. Any system that generates HBr in the presence of a strong enough oxidizer will produce elemental bromine. The HCl and pool chlorinator chemical used here can be substituted by another strong acid and an oxidizer that is active in an acid environment. FUN-FACT: Bromine was in VERY high demand in the 20th century as it was a key component in Ethyl Fluid. And Ethyl fluid was a cute way of saying tetraethyllead blended with 1-2 dibromo and dichloroethanes. It literally put the "lead" in "leaded gasoline"
The bromine and chlorine compounds would react with the lead to prevent solid lead oxide from building up inside the engine, which would ruin it. Instead the lead was converted to lead bromide and chloride which are gases/ or liquids(not too sure) at the tempuratures within the engine. These lead compounds would be exausted outside and into the atmosphere, instead of building up as dust inside the engine block. This kept the engine clean and safe! And also layering the earth's surface in a healthy coating of lead.

The reason for the lack of HCl usage is that Na is displacing the Cl. The (tri/di/mono-chloro)isocyanurate ion hydrolyses to HOCl, and then:
  HOCl + 2Br- + H+ => H2O + Br2 + Cl- (all aq, +35kJ/mol)
With Na+ and the remaining (chloro)isocyanurate as spectators. In conjuction with the hydrolysis this replaces a Chloro group with a Na+. In principle this should yield the trisodium salt without any HCl, but the TCCA isn't very soluble and the hydrolysis of the (chloro)isocyanuric acids is pretty poor; low pH will help drive everything along. If you have access to NaDCCA or even straight DCCA, you might find that the HCl is superfluous and any strong acid will do.
